title: 114_hr2712
content: The Act titled "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes sections on findings, a prospective reporting system, protection of dependent privacy, electronic statements, GAO studies, and an eligibility verification process for ACA subsidies. The Act "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" aims to minimize compliance burdens under the Affordable Care Act while protecting individual privacy. It includes a prospective reporting system. The Act "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Secretary of the Treasury within 180 days of enactment. Employers can report their information for plan years starting after December 31, 2015. The Act mandates a voluntary reporting system for employers to certify coverage details for employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees. Employers must report coverage details, including value requirements, affordability safe harbors, availability to full-time employees, and waiting periods, 60 days before the open enrollment period under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act for each calendar year. The process includes ensuring secure access to information for Exchanges, the Data Services Hub, and the IRS to carry out their missions related to eligibility determinations for premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. Additionally, it allows agencies to follow up with employers to obtain necessary information. The Affordable Care Act includes a process for agencies to follow up with employers to obtain necessary information for eligibility determinations. Employers using the system can provide updates on coverage changes for employees. Employers can provide prospective reporting through a system created under the Affordable Care Act. This allows them to meet certain requirements for the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including satisfying return and statement requirements for the calendar year in which the plan year ends. Employers can use third parties to complete the filing required under the Affordable Care Act without affecting their liability. Employers can use third parties to complete the filing required under the Affordable Care Act without affecting their liability. Each Exchange established under the Affordable Care Act must notify employers when an employee or dependent enrolls in a qualified health plan through the Exchange. SEC. 4 amends Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow substitution of name and date of birth for TINs for dependents if not collected before 2014. The effective date is 60 days after enactment. SEC. 5 pertains to electronic statements. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements if consent has been given by the individual to receive them electronically from their employer. Similarly, Section 6055(c) is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements relating to health insurance coverage. The amendment allows for electronic delivery of statements under Section 6055(c) of the Internal Revenue Code if consent has been given by the individual. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2015. The amendment allows for electronic delivery of statements under Section 6055(c) of the Internal Revenue Code if consent has been given by the individual. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2015. GAO STUDIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for tax credits or subsidies from 2014 to 2016. The study will evaluate employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, focusing on data elements, notification process development, sufficiency of information provided to employers, total number of notifications sent, timeline of notifications, and differences in the notification process. The study will assess employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, including data elements, notification process development, information sufficiency, total notifications sent, notification timeline, differences in the process, challenges faced, and recommendations. Additionally, it will examine whether the Secretary of Health and Human Services has established a separate appeals process for employers to challenge eligibility determinations as required by the Act. The Comptroller General will conduct a study evaluating the prospective reporting system established under section 3 of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant Senate and House committees within one year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will evaluate the reporting system established under section 3 of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. A report on the study results will be submitted to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll individuals in a qualified health plan annually, as long as eligibility for subsidies is redetermined and changes in premiums and income are considered. Reenrollment limitations apply if the marketplace does not follow the specified processes for an individual. The marketplace may not automatically reenroll an individual into a qualified health plan with subsidies if current income information is not provided for redetermination. This section aligns with guidance on annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments issued by CMS in 2015. The Secretary will establish rules for annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments for coverage and tax credits in the marketplace. Enrollees must provide authorization for disclosure of information and updated income details annually to maintain eligibility for subsidies. In this section, the marketplace requests updated income information annually to verify eligibility for credits or cost-sharing reductions. Enrollees are also provided with timely notices about rules for annual redeterminations and reenrollments. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange established under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
